newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: FOCUS - Slovenia port shares pushed down.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Slovenia port shares pushed down.

text.p: Shares in Slovenia's only port, Luka Koper LKPG.LJ, making its debut on the Ljubljana bourse on Wednesday, slumped amid active trading as investors rushed to cash in profits.

Luka Koper closed at 2,200 tolars, down from its opening price of 2,600 -- but still way above its issue price of 1,390. Turnover was a high 58,400 shares, dwarfing the second most actively traded Kolinska on just 5,000 lots.
"Luka's shares eased....as investors who bought them on the grey market over the past few months decided to cash in their profits," said Nina Jarc, a trader at Nova Ljubljanska banka.
Luka's shares last traded on the grey market at between 2,000 and 2,100 tolars.
Market analysts said Luka's price could rise significantly if the state, which owns 51 percent of the company's equity, decided to allow foreign investors to buy.
"That will be a decisive factor as far as price and turnover of Luka's shares are concerned," said Danilo Grasic, a trader at Creditanstalt.

"For now foreigners have no chance to buy the share. We asked the ministry of finance to explain the procedure for foreign buying, but have yet to receive a reply," Florian Hellmich, analyst at Investmentbank Austria in Vienna said.
"I expect the government will let foreigners buy up to 10 percent of Luka's equity," said Toni Apollonio, an analyst at bank A banka.
Foreign interest in Luka was high, traders said, because of the port's good earnings and prospects.
"Luka Koper has a very good geographic position and is unlikely to run out of business," Nova Ljubljanska's Jarc said.
The port, located on the northern shores of the Adriatic, near the Italian border, turned in a net profit of 877.4 million tolars ($6.4 million) in 1995, up from 646.1 million in 1994.
Sales jumped to 7.2 billion tolars from 6.2 billion.
Cargo traffic rose to 6.7 million tonnes in 1995 from 6.3 million a year earlier. The port said it expected cargo figures to grow to 7.5 million tonnes by the year 2000.
The company said it expected the state to approve foreign buying, although the finance ministry has so far remained quiet.
"Recently we had several visits of investment companies from the U.S., Austria, Great Britain and Italy who were interested in buying our shares," said Luka chief executive Bruno Koralic.
The company listed 4.66 million shares with a nominal value of 1,000 tolars a share, representing 33.3 percent of the firm's equity.
